column5: |Aggregate Zone
column6: |Single lookup that contains results from black exploit and policy lists.

column2: |Lists individual IP addresses that have sent mail to spam traps. And some manual added netblocks.
column4: |For automated listings 5.6 days after last event manual additions are permanent.

column2: |Lists IP addresses behaving in a way that indicates the IP is compromised infected proxy VPN TOR malware
|Lists IP addresses that should not be connecting directly to MX such as residential IPs etc.
column5: |Lists ranges that have generic or templated rDNS. Individual IPs can be delisted immediately via web.

column2: |Lists domains seen in spam hitting traps.
column5: |Can be used as an RHSBL and a URIBL.

column2: |Lists domains that are newly observed (first use)
column5: |Based on historical passive DNS data lists domains first seen in the wild within the last 25 hours).

column2: |Lists short URLs (SHA-1 hashed) seen in traps.
column5: |Created to handle popular shorteners that are misused to hide domains from blacklisting.

column2: |Lists URLs of online drive services (SHA-1 hashed) seen in traps.
column5: |Current only listing Google Drive and Yandex Disk URLs that are used to avoid domain blacklisting.

column3: | Extremely conservative list of single IP4 addresses that produce exclusively spam/malware as indicated by the GBUdb IP Reputation system. Most systems should be able to safely reject connections based on this list.
column4: | Automatic: IPs are added when the GBUdb "cloud" statistics reach a probability figure that indicates 95% of messages produce a spam/malware pattern match and a confidence figure that indicates sufficient data to trust the probability data.
column5: | Automatic: Continuous while reputation statistics remain bad. Warning: Produces false positives and has no remedy/removal process. IPs are dropped quickly if the statistics improve (within an hour). IPs are dropped within 36 hours (typ) if no more messages are seen (dead zombie).
column6: | Source data is derived from a global network of Message Sniffer filtering nodes in real-time. Truncate data is updated from statistics every 10 minutes.
column7: Warning: Unreliable as it produces false positives. It is impossible to find additional information or to manually troubleshoot the problem. It is based on results created by their proprietary software running a proprietary algorithm.

column3: | Single IP addresses which only send UBE. Specializing in snowshoe spam and other 'under the radar' spams which evade many other DNSBLs. Has FP-level comparable to Zen.
column4: | Automatic (upon receipt of a spam to a real person's mailbox) with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
column5: | Typically an automatic expiration 11 days after the last abuse was seen but with some exceptions
column6: | Spam samples are always kept on file for each listing. Removal requests are manually reviewed and processed without fees.

column2: | Lists /24 blocks of IP addresses which usually only send UBE and containing at least several addresses which are confirmed emitters of junk mail. Collateral listings are kept to a minimum because subsections are often carved from /24 listings when spammers and legit senders share the same /24 block.
column3: | Automatic once at least several IP addresses from a given block are individually listed on ivmSIP with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
column4: | Expiration time increases to many weeks as the fraction of IP addresses in the /24 block in question sending junk mail increases
column5: | Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

column2: | Comparable to uribl.com and surbl.org this is a list of IP addresses and domains which are used by spammers in the clickable links found in the body of spam messages
column3: | Automatic (upon receipt of a spam to a real person's mailbox) with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
column4: | Typically an automatic expiration several weeks after the last abuse was seen.
column5: | Spam samples are always kept on file for each listing. Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

column3: | Single IP addresses that send mail to [[spamtrap]]s
column4: | Automatic by a cluster of more than 60 trapservers
column5: | Automatic expiration 7 days after the last abuse was seen optionally express delisting for a small fee.
column6: | UCEPROTECT's primary and the only independent list

column2: | This lists the individual IPs (/32s) that are infected with malware worms and Trojans; third party exploits such as open proxies; or devices controlled by botnets. The constantly updated list is designed to protect networks from malware and spam by preventing mailservers from accepting connections from compromised computing devices.
column4: | Varies under a month self removal via [[Composite Blocking List]] lookup.
column5: | Consists of the [[Composite Blocking List]]

column2: | This list is a real-time database of raw and filtered feeds that provides additional information on hijacked IP addresses. The eXBL is available to selected security organizations and cyber incident response teams.
column4: | Varies under a month self removal via [[Composite Blocking List]] lookup.
column5: | Consists of the [[Composite Blocking List]]

column2: | Domains owned by spammers and used for spam or other malicious purposes. This blocklist also contains domains owned by non-spammers which are used for legitimate purposes but have been hijacked by spammers.
column3: | Ranking of over 80 different metrics and machine learning
column4: | A few days. Self-removal generally allowed.

column2: | This list provides detailed information on each domain listing and is available via an API. This enables you to query the DBL engine returning a JSON record for each domain that you are investigating.
column4: The Enhanced Domain Blocklist (eDBL) helps you to track a particular domain's score over a longer period or combine Domain Blocklist data with information from your own threat intelligence platform.
column7: | A few days. Self-removal generally allowed.

column2: | This list includes IP address ranges for end-user devices such as home routers smart TVs and other Information of Things (IoT) devices from which email should never be sent. This protects networks from the potential of being compromised by malware spread by botnet command and controller servers (C;Cs).
column3: | Manual by providers controlling the IPs or by Spamhaus PBL Team
column5: | Should not be confused with the MAPS DUL and Wirehub Dynablocker lists

column2: | This list contains the following content areas: Cryptowallet (Bitcoin etc.) Malware and Email addresses.
column4: Hash Blocklists (HBL) are lists of cryptographic hashes associated with malicious content as opposed to IP addresses or domains. They are extremely useful for filtering fraudulent emails coming from ISPs domains or IP addresses that Spamhaus is unable to list e.g. Gmail. Additionally they can block emails containing malware files.
column5: | Manual by providers controlling the IPs or by Spamhaus PBL Team

column2: | This lists newly registered domains for 24 hours. Domains that have just been registered are rarely used by legitimate organizations immediately. Cybercriminals register and burn 100s of domains daily.
column4: The Zero Reputation Domain (ZRD) blocklist helps to protect your users from clicking on links and visiting newly registered domains until it is established that they are not associated with zero day attacks; phishing bot-herding spyware and ransomware campaigns.
column5: | Automated

column2: | A single lookup for querying the SBL XBL and PBL databases.

column8: Codes are as follows: (ie. General spam single IP result 127.0.0.1)
column9: # general spam Sending spam to our spam traps.
column10: # Removal request made but missing required information please make a new request and be sure to complete the form properly.
column11: # Does not follow valid can-spam rules for newsletters / lists.
column12: # Not RFC compliant server errors or improper configuration.
column13: # Repeat offenders these are IP's that have been removed and listed again (3) or more times in a short period of time.
column14: # Bouncing email to the wrong server RFC-non-compliant configurations.
column15: # Relay or Open relay with reports of spam.
column16: # bouncing spoofed emails you need to disable bounce of spoofed emails in order to get de listed.
column17: # Fraud/Scam emails malware or illegal/abusive content.
